results.title: Woman demon human = Ren Gui Qing [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Huang Shuqin and Shanghai Film Studio
results.brief_description: Directed by one of China’s most prominent female directors this highly expressionistic, psychological drama, based on a true story, focuses on the unconventional career of a famous Chinese Opera actress. Told in flashbacks, the film traces her life on the stage from the 1950s to the 1980s. The initial hostility she receives from the public for embracing male roles, turns to admiration when, defying traditions and conventions, she becomes the first woman to play the lead male role in the Peking Opera. She becomes famous in her role as Zhong Kui, a great mythical character of Chinese theatre. The character gradually takes on a life of its own becoming an alter ego and sounding board for the actress. Impressive performances and cinematographic artistry combine to create a powerful, visually stunning tale. Cast includes Xu Shouli and Li Baotian. In Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: Hibiscus town = Furong zhen [Widescreen] [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Xie Jin and Shanghai Film Studio
results.brief_description: A romantic melodrama which follows the fortunes of a bean curd seller, Hu Yuyin, through the political turmoil of the early sixties, the purges at the height of the Cultural Revolution in the mid-sixties and the end of mass persecution and rehabilitation of ‘rightists’ in the late seventies. The film spans the period by honing in on Hu’s life in three years (1963, 1966, 1979). Hu, as a small businesswoman, is the target for the hardline militants but she is a survivor. She forms a relationship with Qui, reviled by the militants. Hu and Qui are branded as a ‘black couple’ and reduced to street sweepers. This is veteran director Xie Jin’s attempt to answer the challenge of the ‘Fifth Generation’ filmmakers by making a film with a critical edge. It was a popular success in China. Cast includes Liu Xiaoquing, Jiang Wen and Zheng Zaishi. In Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: The End of the affair
results.creator_credit: Neil Jordan, Stephen Woolley and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: During the Second World War, English novelist Maurice Bendrix (Ralph Fiennes) conducted a five year, illicit affair with a married woman (Julianne Moore). Embittered and bewildered by his lover’s abrupt disappearance after a bomb attack, Maurice has the opportunity to re-enter Sarah’s life after he encounters her husband, Henry (Stephen Rea), shortly after the war. Henry, who maintains a platonic relationship with his wife, suspects that she is having an affair and appeals to Maurice to help him find the truth. Overwhelmed by jealousy, Maurice enlists the services of a private detective on the pretext that he is helping Henry. As the film flashes between the present and the past, the motives for Sarah’s actions are gradually revealed. Graham Greene denied that his novel was based on his own affair with Catherine Walston, despite dedicating it to ‘C’ and giving Sarah’s husband the same name as Catherine’s husband. Cast includes Ian Hart and Jason Isaacs. Music composed and conducted by Michael Nyman. Editing, Tony Lawson. Cinematography, Roger Pratt. Written for the screen by Neil Jordan.

results.title: In praise of love = Eloge de l'amour
results.creator_credit: Jean-Luc Godard, Les Films Alain Sarde, Studio Canal+ and Avventura Films
results.brief_description: In the first part of ‘In Praise of love’ a man is intent on auditioning actors for a film he is making on the relationship between a man and a woman who met in the Resistance to fascism in World War Two. Filmed in stark contrasts of black and white, the film within a film takes second place to philosophical mediations on the replacement of “history by technology” and the displacement of “politics by gospel”. In the film’s last third, the stock changes from black and white film to digital video and the colours have the vividness and expression of post-impressionist painting. An elderly couple are being courted by Hollywood executives to sell their story of meeting in the Resistance and surviving the Holocaust. Their antagonistic grand-daughter, reminding them that Schindler’s widow did not share in the wealth generated by Spielberg’s film of ‘Schindler’s List’, argues against the monolithic tendency of Hollywood to exchange in, profit from, and trivialise the lived experience of others. She also reminds us that her grandparents’ history mirrors that of French philosopher Simone Weil, whose social humanism is of no interest to the business people from Los Angeles. What does all this have to do with love? ‘In Praise of love’ reminds us that not only did Jean-Luc Godard re-invent the grammar of film but that he is also one of cinema’s great romanticists. The discordant sounds and jump-cuts of his earlier films have given way to a more mediative mise-en-scene, but his experimentation with sound and image are still provoking and exciting. This film is a philosophical essay on the changing faces of love, an argument against Hollywood’s monopoly of the image, a melancholy ode to a vanishing Paris, an examination on age, passion and politics, and a celebration of the possibilities in both film and video. At the twilight of his life, Godard has created an ode that still argues for the importance and value in something called history, in something called cinema. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Time after time
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Meyer, Herb Jaffe, Orion Pictures Corporation and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: An extraordinary premise lies at the heart of this fantasy thriller: in nineteenth century London, H.G. Wells (Malcolm McDowell) invents a time machine and inadvertently transports himself as well as the notorious Jack The Ripper (David Warner) to modern day San Francisco. What follows is at turns comic and terrifying as fish-out-of-water Wells seeks out the blood thirsty killer whose brutal rampage continues across the city. Whilst on the surface this picture makes innovative use of the quirks of time travel; underneath, “Time after time” investigates the utopian visions of a nineteenth century idealist as compared to the reality of twentieth century America; a society where Jack The Ripper finds himself thoroughly at home. Cast also includes Mary Steenburgen.

results.title: Henry VIII and his six wives
results.creator_credit: Waris Hussein, Roy Baird and Anglo-EMI Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the BBC television miniseries “The Six wives of Henry VIII” this feature film version combines what was a very successful television series into an equally entertaining and well-received film. It has a quality of richness and power and yet at the same time offers a human, almost vulnerable, side to Henry as he desperately searches for a wife who can produce a son and heir to the throne of England. His life is continually surrounded by plots and conspiracies from those who have ulterior motives as to who Henry should marry. Donald Pleasence puts in an excellent performance as Thomas Cromwell and Keith Michell is truly magnificent as Henry VIII as he physically changes from a proud young man to a quite obese and gout-ridden lonely old man. The six wives are played equally as well by Frances Cuka (Catharine of Aragon), Charlotte Rampling (Anne Boleyn), Jane Asher (Jane Seymour), Jenny Bos (Anne of Cleves), Lynne Frederick (Catharine Howard) and Barbara Leigh-Hunt (Catharine Parr).

results.title: Rita, Sue and Bob too
results.creator_credit: Alan Clarke, Sandy Lieberson, Channel 4, Umbrella Entertainment and Oscar Lewenstein
results.brief_description: Rita, Sue and Bob too is a light-hearted adult comedy set in a working class area of England. The film recalls much of the mood in the 1980s in a working class Britain. Rita (Siobhan Finneran) and Sue (Michelle Holmes), both babysitters for Bob (George Costigan) and Michelle (Leslie Sharp), are coming of age. Bob introduces both Rita and Sue to the adult life and takes them on a journey of sexual orientation whilst in his employ. Made by director Alan Clarke, famous for his portrayal of the working class in films like “Scum” and “Made in Britain”, this film warmly gives life to the details that describe ordinary people and the working class lifestyle.

results.title: i.d.
results.creator_credit: Philip Davis, Sally Hibbin, Metropolis Filmproduktions and Parallax Pictures
results.brief_description: Philip Davis is probably better known as an actor who has played both bit parts and lead roles in film and television (Secrets and lies, In the name of the father, North Square (TV series), Blue ice) but he has also directed several films including “i.d.”, his debut film. Interestingly, the plot for “i.d.” has a close link to that of a film which Philip Davis starred in five years earlier, “The Firm” (dir. Alan Clarke, 1989) where the central theme focused around English soccer violence and soccer gangs. “i.d.” tells the story of a British police detective, John (Reece Dinsdale) who, along with three other officers, is sent undercover to blend in with a group of fanatical soccer fans. Their main goal is to identify the gang leaders (or “generals”) who perpetrate and orchestrate the violence and the reasons, or the driving force, as to why they do it. Soccer hooliganism has become a part of Saturday life in London, but the police suspect there is far more to it than just obsessed hard-drinking fans cutting loose. To discover what really goes on behind the scenes, John starts hanging out with a local league team, Shadwell Town, and its hooligan followers, going to the matches, joining in the rumbles, and doing a lot of hard drinking. It’s not long before John finds himself becoming more and more a part of this life, that he is behaving like the thugs he is trying to set up, and relationships are beginning to take an unexpected turn. Violent and brutal, “i.d” is a realistic portrayal of those involved in soccer hooliganism and of working class England at the time. Cast also includes Richard Graham, Claire Skinner, Sean Pertwee, Saskia Reeves and Warren Clarke.

It’s not long before John finds himself becoming more and more a part of this life, that he is behaving like the thugs he is trying to set up, and relationships are beginning to take an unexpected turn. Violent and brutal, “i.d” is a realistic portrayal of those involved in soccer hooliganism and of working class England at the time. Cast also includes Richard Graham, Claire Skinner, Sean Pertwee, Saskia Reeves and Warren Clarke.

results.title: The Man who shot Liberty Valance
results.creator_credit: John Ford, Willis Goldbeck and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: John Ford’s autumnal western is a surprisingly dark study of the limitations of the masculine values that have underpinned his oeuvre of western film. James Stewart plays an Eastern lawyer, Ransom Stottard, who arrives in a small western town determined to espouse the rule of law not the rule of the gun. But the town is being menaced by a sadistic mob of bandits, led by Liberty Valance (Lee Marvin), who are being bankrolled by rich cattle merchants who are opposed to statehood and any ensuing limitations to their claim for land. Stottard’s belief in the calm rules of his legal profession is opposed to Tom Doniphon’s (John Wayne) belief that only a gun can stop Liberty’s harassment of the townspeople. Culminating in a breathtaking shoot-out at night, “The Man who shot Liberty Valance” stands as one of Ford’s most eloquent films, one in which the rugged individualist ethos that he celebrated in “Stagecoach” and “She wore a yellow ribbon” are shown to be in perpetual conflict with the democratic demands of nationhood. The performances by Wayne and Stewart are amongst those performers’ best, and they are ably supported by Vera Miles, Strother Martin (in one of the few African-American representations depicted in the classical Western genre), Lee Marvin, and in a small but cruelly effective role, by Lee Van Cleef

results.title: Mulan
results.creator_credit: Tony Bancroft, Barry Cook, Pam Coats and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: Set in ancient China, this animated feature focuses on the adventures of a feisty young woman who rejects marriage in order to become a warrior. When the Emperor conscripts recruits to defend China against the invading Huns, Mulan disguises herself as a man and takes her ailing father’s place in the army. Responding to her prayers, her ancestors send a tiny dragon (voiced by Eddie Murphy) to aid her on her quest. In its adaptation of a traditional Chinese folk tale, and its use of Asian actors to voice the key characters, ‘Mulan’ continues Disney’s attempts in the nineties to invest their animated features with a more ethnically diverse tone. The film also departs from the gender stereotyping that characterised the studio’s animated classics. In its portrayal of the young heroine as both physically and intellectually capable, it tapped into the late nineties explosion of strong feminist characters in film and television, initiated by the success of the television series ‘Xena: Warrior Princess’. Voices include Ming-Na Wen, Lea Salonga, Eddie Murphy, Donny Osmond and Harvey Fierstein.
